name: What Was That? Quiz | English | 10 Questions

questions.explanation:
metaphor.

	A metaphor is a comparison that doesn't use "like" or "as".

questions.text: The girl laughed like a hyena.
questions.explanation:
simile.

	A simile is a comparison using "like" or "as."

questions.text: The boy had to go to the party with his friends, because everybody was going.
questions.explanation:
hyperbole.

	A hyperbole is an exaggeration.  The boy's view that "everyone" is going is an exaggeration because not "everyone" is going to the party.

alliteration.

	Alliteration is when the beginning sound is repeated such as the /m/ sound in "Many mice marched madly."

questions.text: What literary device does Swinburn use in this line: "Sister, my sister, O fleet sweet swallow."
questions.explanation:
internal rhyme.

	An internal rhyme is a rhyme within a line.

questions.text: "Buzz" said the bee. What kind of literary word is used to describe "buzz"?
questions.explanation:
onomatopoeia.

	An onomatopoeia is a word that describes a sound.

questions.text: The pony was quiet because he was a little horse.
questions.explanation:
pun.

	A pun is a play on words. When a person has trouble speaking it is said he is "hoarse" the pony can't talk because he's a little "horse".

questions.text: In "The Scarlet Letter" by Nathaniel Hawthorne, Hester Pryne wears a scarlet A. What is this A in the literary world?
questions.explanation:
symbol.

	A symbol is something that represents something else.

assonance.

	Assonance is the repeating of vowel sounds. In this case /ee/ is being repeated.

questions.text: The sun smiled down upon the people in the village.
questions.explanation:
personification.

	Personification is giving human qualities to non human things.
